Tkatchenko reaffirmed diplomatic ties with China

(date: 2026-01-13)

Foreign Affairs Minister Justin Tkatchenko has reaffirmed that Papua New Guinea will continue to strengthen its diplomatic relationship with China, its biggest economic and trade partners, on Friday, January 9th, 2026

In a meeting with Ambassador of the People's Republic of China, His Excellency Yang Xiaoguang, the first for the year, Minister Tkatchenko emphasized PNG's commitment to continue to work together to grow relations and opportunities that will benefit both the people, the produce and the business sector.

Marape flags cabinet re-alignment

(date: 2026-01-13)

Prime Minister James Marape has announced that his government is entering a period of performance-based Cabinet realignment as Papua New Guinea moves into what he described as a decisive “year of reset” following the nation’s 50th Independence anniversary.

Speaking at Government House after the swearing-in of Kompiam-Ambum MP Sir John Pundari, Tewai-Siassi MP Dr Kobby Bomareo and Menyamya MP Solen Loifa as Ministers of State, Prime Minister Marape said the appointments were both a recognition of political balance in the coalition and a strategic move to strengthen government delivery in 2026.

PC Online Tidbits

(date: 2026-01-13)

Visible from space. Goodness!

Our same Henao Drive road from above, we took screenshots of from Google Earth. Guess what. It can be viewed from space. We were right after all. The heavens will have to come down fix this bad road. To make matters worse there is one State Minister and another two MPs that live in the same area, that includes the current Opposition leader. As we said, there needs to be divine intervention here, as even the car dodging the potholes are clearly captured from space all over the place. We thought it was a three-lane road!

The post PC Online Tidbits appeared first on Post Courier.

https://www.postcourier.com.pg/pc-online-tidbits-7/

Banks warn consumers will be hurt by Trump’s 10% cap on credit card interest rates

(date: 2026-01-13)

U.S. banks and financial institutions on Monday pushed back against President Donald Trump’s proposed cap on credit card interest rates, citing new data that showed it would result in millions of American households and small businesses losing access to credit. Trump, who is ‍under pressure to address voter concerns over the cost of living, on Friday called for a one-year cap on credit card interest rates at 10% starting on January 20. He did not provide details on how such a ban would be imposed, and some industry experts said it would require congressional action.

(date: 2026-01-13)

Jafra Lehua Kahealani Depontes, 43, of Kailua-Kona died Oct. 24. She was a loving daughter, wife and mother. Visitation 10:30-11:30 a.m. Sunday, Jan. 18 at Kahaluu Ma Kai. Celebration of life service at 11:30 a.m. Luncheon to follow. Survived by husband, Andrew; daughters, Kilihea, Anaha, One‘ula; father, Jayme (Sabine) Depontes; mother Liane Depontes; brother, Nainoa (Emily) Depontes; stepbrothers. Kane Depontes and Ryan Depontes; grandmother, Nita Depontes; aunts, uncles, a nephew and cousins. Arrangements by Nuuanu Memorial Park and Mortuary.

Lloyds Metals continues community support through new donation

(date: 2026-01-13)

In a major boost for healthcare in Central Bougainville, Lloyds Metals and Energy Ltd (LMEL) has donated a critical consignment of medical supplies to Arawa District Hospital (ADH), addressing a chronic drug shortage that has plagued the facility for years.

The donation comes at a time when the Autonomous Region of Bougainville (AROB) health sector is facing significant logistical challenges. For many patients at Arawa Hospital, a lack of basic medicine has meant receiving prescriptions only to be forced to buy them at expensive private pharmacies, with some even traveling as far as Buka to find essential drugs.

Amata’s awareness PSA reminds U.S. Nationals not to vote in other jurisdictions

(date: 2026-01-12)

Source: Congresswoman Uifa’atali Amata’s D.C. staff

Washington, D.C. —(January 9, 2026) Congresswoman Uifa’atali Amata is reminding U.S. nationals from American Samoa that under current U.S. and state laws they absolutely cannot vote in elections outside of American Samoa unless they personally become U.S. citizens before voting.

“It’s incredibly important to not become confused over this: U.S. nationals cannot vote outside our elections in American Samoa. Even if the poll workers do not stop you from voting, and you have a state driver’s license, it’s still not allowed, and can lead to huge legal problems,” said Congresswoman Amata. “If you want to vote in the United States, you must become a citizen first, even if you’ve lived in a U.S. community for many years.”

“Until we are certain that we have widespread 100 percent awareness of this fact, it’s helpful to have a reminder to be sure the word is out, and protect friends and family from a legal nightmare. It’s very important to make sure your graduating high schoolers who are still U.S. nationals know this clearly when they turn 18 and potentially go away to jobs and college,” Aumua Amata continued. “For those choosing citizenship, I have a bill to help that process for U.S. nationals, but nationals risk prosecution by voting in any state that requires U.S. citizenship to be eligible to vote, unless state law were to expressly provide that U.S. nationals also may vote in that state’s elections.”

Amata has introduced the American Samoa Statutory Nationality and Citizenship Act (H.R. 6158) to help individual U.S. nationals more readily transfer into U.S. citizenship as a personal choice, while not affecting American Samoa’s current status, which for over 125 years has protected the family land and chiefly (matai) systems within the traditional fa’a Samoa (Samoan way).

The bill protects both collective self-determination for American Samoa and the individual rights of U.S. nationals, by enabling elective United States citizenship for individuals, and she will be posting more information about the bill in the months ahead.

“I am saddened by the voting case in Alaska, and I hope the wonderful people of Alaska, where I’ve visited many times, will be forgiving of this mistake by the local U.S. nationals in their community,” Amata concluded. “Rather, I hope that this can become an educational moment, that the Lord can ‘work together for good’ by preventing future problems through public awareness while restoring our people in Alaska with compassion.”

Section:

Local News

Tags:

https://www.samoanews.com/local-news/amatas-awareness-psa-reminds-us-nationals-not-vote-other-jurisdictions

Virtual event today as comment period for Deep Sea Mining in Am Samoa closes

(date: 2026-01-12)

Source: Right to Democracy Press Release

Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA — As the federal government considers opening U.S. territorial waters to deep sea mining, Pacific Island communities and territorial governments are going on record to oppose the imposition of these activities, warning of irreversible harm to ocean ecosystems, cultural lifeways, and the democratic rights of island peoples.

Just hours before the comment period closes this week, Right to Democracy, in partnership with the America the Beautiful for All Coalition, will host a virtual panel examining the federal call to open the waters of the Marianas to deep sea mining and its implications for island communities, ocean ecosystems, and self-determination.

The panel will feature Andra Samoa, Maria Hernández, and Sheila Babauta, all of whom are Right to Democracy Environment & Democracy Fellows, and will be co-moderated by Neil Weare, Co-Director of Right to Democracy, and Angelo Villagomez, Ocean Co-Lead for the America the Beautiful for All Coalition.

Local and national civil society organizations will announce the results of their respective outreach efforts and successes in submitting petitions, letters, and comments to the federal register.

Special guests include Lt. Governor Joshua Tenorio, Speaker Frank Blas, Jr., and others.

The Virtual Panel Will Take Place:

  •           Monday, January 12th at 5:00pm EST, 6:00pm AST, 11:00 am SST (American Samoa)
  •           Tuesday, January 13th at 8:00am ChST (Guam / Northern Mariana Islands)

(date: 2026-01-11)

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn. — Tens of thousands of people marched through Minneapolis on Saturday to decry the fatal shooting of a woman ‌by a U.S. immigration agent, part of more than 1,000 rallies planned nationwide this weekend against the federal government’s deportation drive. The massive turnout in Minneapolis despite a whipping, cold wind underscores how the fatal shooting of 37-year-old Renee Good by an Immigration and Customs Enforce-ment officer on Wednesday has struck a chord, fueling protests in major cities and some towns. Minnesota’s Democratic leaders and the administration of President Donald Trump, a Republican, have offered starkly different accounts of the incident.

Mr Pim is standing as a candidate under the People First Party against 24 candidates to contest his late father’s seat, which was left vacant after he passed away in 2023.

Bougainville Solar Plant generates first SOE revenue, lighting up Buin

(date: 2026-01-11)

In a significant step toward economic self-reliance, the Bougainville Power and Water Corporation Limited (BPWCL) has begun generating its own revenue, becoming one of the first State-Owned Enterprises (SOEs) under the Autonomous Bougainville Government (ABG) to achieve this status.

This milestone follows the December commissioning of a one-megawatt solar power plant in Buin, South Bougainville. The plant now provides reliable electricity to approximately 250 households, schools, businesses, and health facilities in the town and its surrounding communities.

(date: 2026-01-09)

New Porgera Limited (NPL) has successfully completed maintenance works on three staff houses, marking the first project delivered under the Infrastructure Tax Credit Scheme (TCS) since the restart of the New Porgera operation. The Paiam Hospital is the district hospital for the Porgera-Paiela District.

Funded through the TCS at a total cost of over K185,000, the maintenance works commenced in November 2025 and were completed on 31 December 2025.

Australia supports PNG to drive improvement in health systems

(date: 2026-01-09)

The Australasian College of Health Service Management (ACHSM) and the PNG National Department of Health have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to drive improvement in healthcare systems in PNG.

The MOU signed at the annual Asia-Pacific Health Leadership Congress in Darwin establishes a collaborative partnership aimed at strengthening health leadership capacity across PNG. This will support Papua New Guinean health leaders to engage with regional and international peers, and progress the establishment of an official PNG branch of ACHSM.

(date: 2026-01-09)

Mr Malai told the Post-Courier that the Southern Region, especially Western Province, Central, Gulf and Milne Bay are experiencing about 35 to 48 knots regarded as strong gale.

King’s Baton arrives in Papua New Guinea to spark 2026 Commonwealth Games spirit

(date: 2026-01-09)

The King’s Baton officially arrived in Papua New Guinea on Thursday, 8 January, marking a significant milestone in the 500-day global relay leading to the Glasgow 2026 Commonwealth Games.

Originally sent forth by His Majesty The King from Buckingham Palace in March 2025, the Baton represents a tradition that connects and excites communities across the Commonwealth. This leg of the journey highlights the power of sport to inspire youth and strengthen international ties through inclusion and respect.

A landmark road development project launched to transform Poroma, Nipa and Kutubu corridor

(date: 2026-01-09)

Prime Minister James Marape has officially launched the long-awaited Poroma-Kutubu road sealing project, marking a historic turning point for a region that has served as Papua New Guinea’s economic engine for over three decades.

The K371.5 million project, part of the Connect PNG infrastructure program, aims to seal over 100 kilometers of highway, finally linking the remote oil-producing heartland to the rest of the nation with high-quality infrastructure.

PNG Lewas register convincing win at Australian Country Championships

(date: 2026-01-08)

The PNG Lewas continued their strong showing at the Toyota Australian Country Cricket Championships (Female Division) with a commanding 40-run victory over South Australia Country Women in a T20 match at Barossa Park, Lyndoch.

After winning the toss and electing to bat, the Lewas posted a competitive total of 133 for 7 from their allotted 20 overs. The batting effort was backed by a disciplined bowling display, with PNG restricting South Australia to 93 for 7 in 20 overs to seal a comfortable win.

(date: 2026-01-08)

The 2026 Commonwealth Games King’s Baton Relay was met with a vibrant celebration today as it arrived in the historic stilt village of Hanuabada, the ancestral home of the Motu-Koitabu people.

National Capital District (NCD) Governor Powes Parkop was on hand to receive the Baton, marking a key milestone in the Port Moresby leg of the relay. The ceremony highlighted the village's unique sporting heritage, with the Baton at one point travelling by water to navigate the sprawling overwater.

Obituaries for January 8

(date: 2026-01-08)

George Yuzuru Ikeda, 77, of Pahoa died Oct. 17 at Legacy Hilo Rehabilitation and Nursing Center. Born in Japan, he was a retired county Parks and Recreation district supervisor. Private services held. No flowers or koden (monetary gifts). Online condolences: dodomortuary.com. Survived by wife, Mae Ikeda of Pahoa; son, Reid (Anela) Ikeda of Hilo; brothers-in-law, Ronald Nakamoto of Hilo, Ray Nakamoto of Waimea and Alan (Joni) Nakamoto of Waikoloa; sisters-in-law, Ilona (Mark) Haggerty of Waimea, Doreen Nakamoto and Viola Alfson of California, Joyce Ikeda of Hilo; nephews and nieces. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.

(date: 2026-01-08)

The township of Jiwaka in the Ramu Grid will experience an emergency power outage on Friday, January 9, 2026, from 9:00 am to 4:00 pm for maintenance work.

This power outage is due to maintenance work on a faulty tap on Kudjip's 66kV/22kV Transformer, which has been causing low voltage in the township area.

The continuous rain has flooded most of the low-lying areas of ward 11, covering food gardens, overflowing toilet pits, and water wells, and it is a serious concern regarding the daily lives of people.

NARI, JICA partner to roll out SHEP Farming Project in East New Britain

(date: 2026-01-07)

The National Agricultural Research Institute (NARI), in partnership with the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) and the East New Britain Provincial Government, has announced the implementation of the Project for Capacity Development of Sustainable Integrated Farming System using the SHEP Approach in East New Britain Province.

The project, which will be coordinated from NARI Keravat, will be rolled out across all four districts of the province. SHEP, or Smallholder Horticulture Empowerment Project, is designed to transform smallholder farming by shifting practices from the traditional “grow and sell” approach to a more market-oriented “grow to sell” strategy.

Chris the walkabout salesman

(date: 2026-01-07)

Christopher Molas Jnr is an entrepreneur with a knack for door-to-door sales. He makes up to K700-K800 selling everyday household items as a "travelling salesman" on the streets of Buka, Arawa, Buin and other locations in Bougainville.

Chris hails from Lemankoa, Haku Constituency and Wakunai in the Rau Constituency of Central Bougainville. He started his "liklik bisnis" in 2018 and fondly recalls being drawn into entrepreneurship by friends and relatives who were actively involved in the informal sector.

Maduro opponent Machado vows to return to Venezuela, wants an election

(date: 2026-01-07)

WASHINGTON — Venezuela’s main opposition leader, Maria Corina Machado, has vowed to return home quickly, praising U.S. President Donald Trump for toppling ‌her enemy Nicolas Maduro and declaring her movement ready to win a free election. Trump appears, however, to hope for now to work with interim President Delcy Rodriguez and other senior officials from Maduro’s government, disappointing the opposition and contributing to nervousness in Venezuela. Venezuelan and U.S. officials are discussing the export of Venezuelan crude to U.S. refiners, five government, industry and shipping sources told Reuters. “I’m planning to go back to Venezuela as soon as possible,” said Machado, 58, who escaped from Venezuela in disguise in October to receive the Nobel Peace Prize, which she dedicated to Trump.

North Bougainville MP Francesca Semoso delivers K1 million worth of medical equipment and infrastructure to Buka General Hospital

(date: 2026-01-07)

North Bougainville MP and Assistant Speaker of the National Parliament, Francesca Rianna Semoso, has handed over a range of essential medical equipment, vehicles, and infrastructure improvements valued at part of a K2 million commitment to Buka General Hospital, emphasising her ongoing support for strengthening healthcare services in the region.

In a ceremony witnessed by key health officials and community leaders, Ms Francesca Semoso presented the items on behalf of her K2 million funding allocation presented earlier on 16 May 2025. The handover was received by the Minister for Health and North Bougainville Women's Representative, Delourdes Semoso, alongside Buka General Hospital CEO Dr. Tommy Wotsia. Also present were Acting Health Secretary Mr. Matthew Monei, Tsitalato Constituency Member, Mr John Bosco Ragu, Buka Town Manager, Mr. Fidelis Semoso, chairpersons of the Community Government, and members of the general public.

PNG Correctional Services officers complete NSW study tour

(date: 2026-01-06)

A team of senior officers from Papua New Guinea Correctional Services (PNGCS), led by Acting Commissioner Bernard Nepo, has completed a week-long study tour in New South Wales, Australia, aimed at strengthening correctional services in Papua New Guinea.

The study tour was supported by the Australia–PNG Law and Justice Partnership and hosted by Corrective Services NSW (CSNSW). During the visit, officers were exposed to a range of correctional operations, including custodial management, rehabilitation programmes, community-based corrections, specialised security protocols, and prison industries.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

(date: 2026-01-06)

Seamount crusts/Photo courtesy of NOAA According to the U.S. Geological Survey, the following minerals are likely present in the CNMI waters:   Cobalt-rich iron-manganese crusts occur on the sea­mounts located east of the Mariana Trench. Data for crusts from nearby seamounts indicate that crusts on sea­mounts within that sector of the CNMI EEZ have an excel­lent potential to be thick and have high contents of cobalt, nickel, and platinum. It is recommended that these sea­mounts be explored...

Betelnut chewing and smoking ban enforced in Madang CBD

(date: 2026-01-06)

The restriction on betelnut chewing and smoking in public places in the Madang Central Business District is a national law and not a policy of the Madang Urban Local Level Government.

Madang Governor and Provincial Member Ramsey Pariwa clarified this following recent arrests in Madang town after enforcement began on Thursday, January 1, 2026. Governor Pariwa said the law was enacted by Parliament and carries the same legal weight and penalties as other national laws.

Cash-trapping scam discovered on local bank ATM

(date: 2026-01-05)

By

Samoa News staff

reporters@samoanews.com

Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA — Customers of the Territorial Bank of American Samoa (TBAS) have been actively voicing their concerns on social media about a troubling cash-trapping scheme reported at the bank's Automated Teller Machine (ATM) located within the Laufou Shopping Center in Nuʻuuli.

Several social media accounts have surfaced, detailing allegations that certain individuals have strategically applied tape to the ATM’s cash dispenser. This disturbing tactic is designed to misappropriate customer withdrawals. One account described a troubling incident in which a customer attempted to withdraw funds from an ATM. Although he received a receipt indicating that the transaction was successful, he was shocked to find that no physical cash was dispensed. Upon closer inspection of the cash dispenser, he discovered tape blocking the exit, with the cash he had attempted to withdraw stuck to it.

This alarming incident has since been reported to TBAS management. Cash-trapping scams have become a troubling trend, reported in communities across the United States and internationally. These schemes typically involve placing a device or obstruction over the cash dispenser slot to prevent the release of funds. In these scenarios, the customer’s account is debited, yet no cash is dispensed. Victims often assume the ATM is malfunctioning and leave, allowing the perpetrator to return, remove the obstruction, and claim the trapped cash.

In response to these concerns, TBAS President and Chief Executive Officer Owen Perry addressed local media, confirming the bank's awareness of the troubling reports. He indicated that TBAS is actively investigating the situation, which appears to be limited to this ATM location for now. “Upon learning about the issue, the bank quickly contacted the Department of Public Safety and is cooperating fully while conducting an internal review,” Perry stated.

Perry further emphasized, “Our ATMs undergo regular monitoring and inspections, and we are continually evaluating and enhancing our security protocols across all locations.” TBAS strongly encourages any customer who experiences difficulties at a TBAS ATM or notices any anomalies to contact the bank immediately, enabling a swift response and resolution.

Due to the ongoing investigation, Perry noted that the bank cannot share specific details about the incidents at this time. “Our top priority is to ensure the safety of our customers while maintaining the integrity of our banking services,” he remarked.

Section:

Local News

Tags:

cash trapping scam

(date: 2026-01-05)

J   Across Guam and the wider Western Pacific, the ocean is more than geography; it is livelihood, culture, and legacy. For island communities whose histories, economies and identities are inseparable from the sea, decisions made far from our shores carry lasting consequences. As federal discussions advance regarding seabed mining in the Western Pacific, voices from Guam and neighboring islands are rising to underscore what is at stake: fragile marine ecosystems, indigenous cultural...

Solar-powered water upgrade for Yanga Village

(date: 2026-01-05)

Residents of Yanga Village near Lae can now enjoy improved access to clean and reliable water after Ahi Investment Limited funded the repair and upgrade of the community’s bore water system.

The project, delivered through the Ahi Charitable Trust, restored a damaged water tank and upgraded the system using solar-powered technology. The bore water system was originally donated by the Lae City Authority, but one of its tanks was damaged and became non-functional, affecting water supply for the village.

New Guinea’s forests

(date: 2026-01-04)

New Guinea is staggeringly rich in life. Occupying just 0.5% of Earth’s land surface, it hosts an estimated 5-8% of all species. This abundance is reflected in more than 2,800 orchid species, over 1,000 butterflies and around 800 birds. Over half of its known species are found nowhere else on Earth.

The post New Guinea’s forests appeared first on Post Courier.

https://www.postcourier.com.pg/new-guineas-forests/

Visitation 8:30-10 a.m. Friday, Jan. 23, at St. John’s Catholic Church in Kealakekua. Mass at 10 a.m. Burial to follow at Kona Memorial Park in Holualoa. Casual attire. Survived by son, James Mark (Roslyn) Thomas of Kona; stepchildren, Yolanda (Rick) Bautista of Honolulu, Alfred Estencion of Kona, Darren Estencion of Maui and Eldaine Barawis of Kailua-Kona; godchildren, Casey Keohuloa, Pikake Keohuloa and Trina Kauhaihao; three grandchildren; nieces, nephews, and cousins. (date: 2026-01-04)

Central Provincial Government moves to protect rural producers from market harassment

(date: 2026-01-04)

The Central Provincial Government (CPG), led by Deputy Governor and Chairman for Law & Order, Desmond Baira, is initiating high-level meetings to address the systemic harassment of rural producers supplying the National Capital District (NCD).

Farmers, fishermen, and betelnut growers from Central Province report growing intimidation and extortion when transporting goods to major NCD hubs, including Gordons, Boroko, and Koki. A primary concern is the predatory behaviour of "middlemen" who demand unauthorised "carrying fees."

(date: 2026-01-02)

In the 1960s and 1970s, the University of Papua New Guinea and the University of the South Pacific redesigned and decolonized their curriculum. They replaced the established British colonial model with Pacific oratory and a growing body of Oceanian writing at the center of the syllabus.

Access Road to Water PNG washed out by heavy rain in Popondetta

(date: 2026-01-02)

Heavy rainfall on New Year’s Eve has left the access road to the Water PNG facility in Popondetta severely damaged, creating significant hazards for motorists and pedestrians.

The damage was reportedly exacerbated by a blocked stormwater drain. According to local resident Mathew Malpaim, a discarded tyre was dumped into the drainage system, obstructing the natural flow of water.

Don re-signs Edene on a new two-year contract

(date: 2026-01-01)

The Dons have handed their 2026 campaign a massive boost with the confirmation that star winger Edene Gebbie has committed his future to the club. The reigning Player of the Year has officially signed a new two-year contract extension, keeping him at the heart of the squad’s ambitious push for the play-offs.

The 30-year-old Papua New Guinea international proved to be a revelation last season, finishing the year with a remarkable strike rate of 25 tries in just 22 appearances. His decision to extend his stay is a significant statement of intent for the club as they look to build on the momentum of the previous season.

(date: 2026-01-01)

OK Tedi Mining Limited (OTML) has donated four 200-litre drums of zoom to the Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary (RPNGC) Water Police Directorate in Port Moresby.

The donation reaffirmed OTML’s commitment to community safety and law and order. The fuel support will enable the Water Police team to increase maritime patrols and maintain law and order across Fairfax Harbour, safeguarding it, the surrounding areas and the Motukea logistics corridor.

Samoa News staff

reporters@samoanews.com

Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA — December 19, 2025) Pavaia’i Elementary School has received national recognition through the America Celebrates display, as artwork created by students from Ms. Loimata Siona’s 4th grade class were selected for exhibition at the White House. The program features handcrafted ornaments representing every U.S. state, territory, and the District of Columbia, all showcased around the iconic National Christmas Tree.

The ornaments submitted by Ms. Siona’s elementary class were designed during the previous school year, reflecting the culture, pride, and unique identity of American Samoa.

Each year, the America Celebrates program provides students across the nation with an opportunity to represent their home state or territory through original artwork that becomes part of a holiday tradition in the nation’s capital.

The National Christmas Tree, along with the accompanying state and territory ornaments, will remain on display at the White House through January 1, 2026.

Visitors from around the world will have the opportunity to admire the creativity, talent, and cultural expression of young artists from across the United States and its territories.

Visit the nationaltree.org/ornaments/american-samoa/ to view the complete collection of the American Samoa state ornaments.

Section:

Local News

Tags:

White House National Christmas Tree Exhibit

https://www.samoanews.com/local-news/pavaiai-elementary-artwork-displayed-white-house-national-christmas-tree-exhibit

Driving and parking on Malae o le Talu “no longer tolerated”

(date: 2025-12-31)

By

Samoa News staff

reporters@samoanews.com

Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA — The Governor’s Office has officially given notice that parking and driving on the Malae o le Talu will no longer be tolerated. However, there is “no teeth” to the notice, as no fines for the offense are posted and the question of enforcement arises, as the Department of Public Safety has been seen as one of the worst offenders — using the Malae as a parking zone for their vehicles.

In the notice posted on the Office of the Governor’s webpage and addressed to the Secretary of Samoan Affairs, CEOs, Presidents and Executive Directors of Authorities, Directors. Agency and Office Heads — it says in part, “This prohibition applies to all ASG employees, contractors, and agents operating government vehicles, regardless of purpose or duration.”

Effective immediately, the following measures are hereby implemented:

a)      All American Samoa Government (ASG) vehicles and privately owned and operated vehicles are strictly prohibited from driving or parking on the Malae. This prohibition applies to all ASG employees, contractors, and agents operating government vehicles, regardless of purpose or duration.

b)      The Department of Parks and Recreation shall provide technical assistance, resources, and operational support to the village Pulenu’u and Leoleo Nuu in their efforts to protect the Malae.

c)      All ASG personnel and privately owned vehicles must utilize designated or alternate parking areas in proximity to the Malae.

Emergency vehicles responding to actual emergencies may access the Malae only to the extent absolutely necessary to address the emergency situations.

All agency heads, directors, and supervisors are responsible for ensuring that employees under their supervision are informed of and comply with this directive.

Preserving the cultural, historical, and recreational use of the Malae is a matter of territorial significance and requires the full cooperation of all ASG personnel.

A memo, dated December 23, 2025, and signed by Governor Pulaali’i Nikolau Pula notes that “the Malae o le Talu (Malae) has been a central gathering place of profound historical, cultural, and ceremonial significance to the people of American Samoa for over 125 years, hosting village events, governmental functions, and community recreation.

“Vehicular traffic has severely damaged the Malae, compacting soil, destroying grass, and creating unsafe divots, hindering full use and enjoyment of this communal gathering place.”

Samoa News has published photos of the “No Parking” signs on the Malae, especially when the Governor’s Office moved into their new location at the newly renovated old ASB-ANZ Bank building — the Malae o le Talu is located directly across the street. Photos published also included the Department of Public Safety parking their vehicles on the Malae.

Looking forward together to all the possibilities for a wonderful new year

(date: 2025-12-30)

By

Samoa News staff

reporters@samoanews.com

Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA — In this beautiful photo, Congresswoman Uifa’atali Aumua Amata remembered our loved ones far away due to military service, collegiate studies, or careers in the states.

“May God especially bless and each of them and these families, with ‘many happy returns’ to our island home. This Christmas, we keep our Toa o Samoa especially in our prayers – thank you to each one for your service and sacrifice! Just this week, Congress sent next year’s 3.8 percent pay raise for our military to the President to be signed into law, as part of a busy December.

“We look forward together to all the possibilities for a wonderful new year. May each of us celebrate this special season with joyful and charitable hearts.”

Ring in the New Year with promises of renewal, reflection and hope

(date: 2025-12-30)

By

Samoa News staff

reporters@samoanews.com

Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA — In observance of the New Year holiday, Governor Pulaali’i Nikolau Pula has announced that the government will officially take two days off — Thursday, January 1, 2026 and Friday, January 2nd. However, Wednesday, while not a holiday, will be a half day, with an early release from work at 12p.m.

As per usual on a government holiday all government offices will be closed, and normal operations will be suspended. Employees of the American Samoa Government who are not required to perform essential services shall be excused from duty. Those employees whose duties are essential and are required to work on these holidays shall receive holiday compensation in accordance with applicable laws and regulations.

“Government operations shall resume under normal business hours on Monday, January 5th 2026.

“The New Year marks a time of renewal, reflection, and hope as we look ahead to new opportunities and responsibilities. It is also a moment to give thanks for God’s guidance and blessings throughout the past year. Employees are encouraged to spend this time with family and loved ones, reflect on the yer past, and prepare for the year ahead with renewed purpose, unity, and commitment in serving our community.”

Governor Puaali’i extends his sincere appreciation for their continued service and dedication to the people of the Territory. “May the New Year bring you good health, success, and prosperity.

Samoa News should note that the governor is currently off island, with no return date currently announced.

The US Post Office Service will be closed New Year’s Day, returning on Friday, Jan. 2nd, as per normal federal holiday.

The Territorial Bank of American Samoa (TBAS) will close early at 12 pm, on Wednesday, December 31, 2025; on Thursday, Jan 1, 2026 it will be closed; and, it will be open on Friday, Jan. 2nd for full service.

Don’t forget American Samoa is the last “inhabited” country to ring in the New Year — if you want to see the last sunset of 2025 in the Territory, take a ride out to Poloa. On the other hand, if you want to experience the first New Year celebration in the world, you need to fly to Samoa, with the holidays experiencing some of the the busiest flight times for the inter-island airlines.

For StarKist Samoa its cannery shutdown continues for the Christmas and New Year holidays. The shutdown allows for major maintenance work and prepares the cannery for the new year, with the company slated to begin production of pet food in 2026.

With more than 80% of the cannery workforce of more than 2,000 being from Samoa, they have headed home for the holidays. The cannery did arrange for a charter of the Lady Samoa ferry to take its employees to Samoa during Christmas week. It’s unknown if a return-trip ferry has been chartered.

The company’s first day of production for 2026 is scheduled for Monday, Jan. 5th.

Usually New Year in the Territory highlights its NY Eve’s church services before the bars begin to fill to ring in the brand new year.

On New Year Day, look for family or company barbecues at the public beaches and parks. Most grocery stores will be open, with specialty stores and companies usually closing on that day, with all returning to full service on Friday.

According to the National Weather Service- Pago Pago, the weather forecast for New Year’s Day is partly cloudy, isolated showers, highs in the upper 80s, and variable winds up to 10 mph. It looks like mostly a sunny day.

From Thursday night through to Friday, its still partly cloudy however, scattered showers are forecast.

Friday night through Sunday, the weather is mostly cloudy with numerous showers — definitely expect rain throughout the weekend.

For the public’s safety, the police are continuing their Enforcement initiative that began about 2 weeks ago, marking the beginning of a focused effort to enhance road safety during the busy festive season.

Commissioner of Public Safety Taaga Saite Moliga announced the Enforcement initiative noting the deployment of strategically placed roadblocks throughout the community to identify and evaluate drivers suspected of being under the influence of alcohol or drugs. He noted these roadblocks would be strategically placed in response to real-time traffic patterns, focusing on high-traffic areas during peak travel periods to maximize visibility and effectiveness.

The DPS is maintaining its Holiday Enforcement program, through Saturday, January 3, 2026.

Samoa News will have an issue tomorrow, December 31st, New Year’s eve day and will be off on Thursday, Jan 1st and Friday, Jan. 2nd, returning on Monday, Jan 5th, 2026.

Happy New Year — American Samoa. Be safe, and with God’s grace may we ring in the New Year remembering to be kind to one another.

Section:

Local News

NEW YEAR 2026

The world wants more ube. Philippine farmers are struggling to keep up

(date: 2025-12-30)

BENGUET PROVINCE, Philippines — In New York City, people line up outside a bakery before it opens to buy a brioche doughnut whose glaze shines a startling purple. In Paris, people sip purple-colored lattes with a mellow, nutty scent. In Melbourne, Australia, a purple tinge gives hot cross buns a gentle sweetness.

https://www.hawaiitribune-herald.com/2025/12/30/nation-world-news/the-world-wants-more-ube-philippine-farmers-are-struggling-to-keep-up/

(date: 2025-12-30)

Perfectua Castanero Babiera, 88, of Hilo died Dec. 1 at Life Care Center of Hilo. Born in the Philippines, she was a sorter for Mauna Loa Macadamia Nut Co. and member of the St. Joseph Catholic Church. Visitation 4-6 p.m. Thursday, Jan. 8, at Dodo Mortuary Chapel. Wake service at 6 p.m. Visitation again 8-9:30 a.m. Friday, Jan. 9, at St. Joseph Catholic Church. Mass at 9;30 a.m. Burial to follow at Homelani Memorial Park, Ilima Section. Survived by niece/hanai daughter, Joceyln (Albert Lagronio) Lazaga of Hilo; two grandchildren. nieces and nephews. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.

Organised by the company management and attended by all employees, the event was a testament to the company's spirit. The Corporate Team worked tirelessly to decorate the office reception area; as staff entered the beautifully adorned hall, they were immediately greeted by the festive atmosphere. (date: 2025-12-29)

Vetiver grass is being used by farmers in Markham to reduce flooding, landslides, and soil erosion.

John Gaif, President of the Markham Smart Farmers Association, said vetiver is known as the “Miracle Grass” because of its deep root system. He said the roots can grow up to 15 metres into the soil.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Vetiver grass used to protect farms and infrastructure in Markham appeared first on Post Courier.

https://www.postcourier.com.pg/vetiver-grass-used-to-protect-farms-and-infrastructure-in-markham/

Port Moresby water supply set to recover as raw water quality stabilises

(date: 2025-12-28)

Water supply across the National Capital District is expected to return to normal levels throughout Monday following a successful stabilisation of raw water quality at the main intake.

Water PNG confirmed late Sunday night that turbidity levels (NTU)—which had previously hindered the treatment process—have finally returned to acceptable limits. The improvement in water clarity has allowed technical teams to begin the critical process of restarting the flow to the city's primary treatment facilities.

Fire a big threat in PNG towns

(date: 2025-12-28)

More than 14 small and medium size businesses in Mendi, Southern Highlands are still struggling to accept their loses after two separate fires gutted the buildings they were operating in last week.

The causes of the fires are not known at this stage, however the businesses have lost millions of kina to the fires which have left a population devastated with the locals openly weeping over their town.

PM to create communal reconciliation space in Tari

(date: 2025-12-28)

To strengthen traditional conflict resolution, among his people in Tari, Prime Minister James Marape has announced plans to establish a communal reconciliation space in the Tari Pori District of Hela Province.

“I will buy land the size of a soccer field and convert it into a communal place where we can come together to resolve our problems. Resolve issues among yourselves and do not always wait for police to come,” he said.

Obituaries for December 28

(date: 2025-12-28)

Brian E. Antida, 65, of Hilo died Nov. 17 at home. Born in Hilo, he was an investigator for the Office of the Prosecuting Attorney, and previously with the Department of Liquor Control, a Hawaii County Police Department officer, Hilo Drivers Licensing Department and the former Hukilau Hotel. Visitation 9:30-11 a.m. Saturday (Jan. 3) at Dodo Mortuary Chapel. Memorial prayer service at 11. Casual attire. Survived by wife, Pam Antida of Hilo; daughter, Blake Ann (Jensen) Sato of Hilo; brothers, Warren (Meagan) Antida of San Jose, Calif., John (Chris Gomera-Nicolas) Camero of Mountain View; a granddaughter, aunts, uncles, cousins, nieces and nephews. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.

Hiri East youths establish neighborhood watch to ensure festive season safety

(date: 2025-12-27)

Youths from Ward 4 of the Hiri East Koiari Local Level Government (LLG) area in Central Province have committed to forming a neighbourhood watch team to help maintain peace and security in their community during the festive season.

The initiative involves a dedicated group of youth volunteers maintaining an almost 24-hour presence along roadsides and within the village, operating daily from 6pm to 5am. The increased vigilance has enabled the group to closely monitor the movement of people in the area, particularly intoxicated individuals, helping to deter disturbances and promote harmony within the community.

Judge grants injunction blocking US from detaining British anti-disinformation activist

(date: 2025-12-27)

WASHINGTON — A U.S. judge on Thursday temporarily blocked the Trump administration from detaining British anti-disinformation campaigner Imran Ahmed, after the U.S. permanent resident sued officials over an entry ban for his role in what Washington argues is online censorship. Washington imposed visa bans on Tuesday on Ahmed and four Europeans, including French ‍former EU commissioner Thierry Breton. It accuses them of working to censor freedom of speech or unfairly target U.S. tech giants with burdensome regulation. Ahmed lives in Washington and is believed to be the only of the five currently in the country. The move sparked an outcry from European governments ​who argue regulations and the work of monitoring groups made the internet safer by ​highlighting false information and compelling tech giants to do more to tackle illegal content, including hate speech and child sexual abuse material.

https://www.hawaiitribune-herald.com/2025/12/27/nation-world-news/judge-grants-injunction-blocking-us-from-detaining-british-anti-disinformation-activist/

(date: 2025-12-27)

Obituaries for December 26

(date: 2025-12-26)

Bernard Bertin Noguès, 86, of Waimea died Dec. 9 at Queen’s North Hawaii Community Hospital. Born in Houilles, France, he was a retired teacher and administrator for Hawaii Preparatory Academy and avid golfer, tennis player and fisherman. Visitation 9:30-10:30 a.m. Saturday, Jan. 3, at Annunciation Catholic Church in Waimea. Remembrances and eulogy at 10:30. Mass at 11 a.m. Private burial to follow. Gathering at his home at 2 p.m. Aloha attire. Survived by wife, Mary-Alice Noguès of Waimea; children, Mireille (Manjit Singh) Urbani of Indianapolis, Marguerite (Alan) Heap of Waimea André Noguès of Ashland, Ore., Marina (Bradford Cole) Noguès of Honolulu and Jean Noguès of Waimea; sister, Marina Kaiser of France; three grandchildren and two great-grandchildren; cousins, nieces and nephews. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.

WASHINGTON — ‌The White House has ordered U.S. military forces to focus almost exclusively on enforcing a “quarantine” of Venezuelan oil for at least the next two months, a U.S. official told Reuters, indicating Washington is currently more interested in using economic rather than military means to pressure Caracas. “While military options still exist, the ‍focus is to first use economic pressure by enforcing sanctions to reach the outcome the White House is looking (for),” the official said on Wednesday, speaking on condition of anonymity. While President Donald Trump has been publicly coy about his precise aims regarding Venezuela, he has privately pressured Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro to ​flee the nation, Reuters has reported. Trump said on Monday it would be ​smart for Maduro to leave power.

https://www.hawaiitribune-herald.com/2025/12/25/nation-world-news/white-house-orders-military-to-focus-on-quarantine-of-venezuela-oil/

Atmospheric river drenches Los Angeles, triggers widespread flooding

(date: 2025-12-25)

LOS ANGELES — Torrential rains drenched Southern California on Wednesday, ​unleashing widespread flash flooding ‌as authorities urged motorists to stay ‌off roads and residents living downslope of wildfire-scarred foothills and canyons to evacuate.

https://www.hawaiitribune-herald.com/2025/12/25/nation-world-news/atmospheric-river-drenches-los-angeles-triggers-widespread-flooding/

Palau agrees to take up to 75 migrants from the US

(date: 2025-12-25)

Palau, an archipelago of about 350 small islands in the Pacific Ocean, has signed a “memo of understanding” with the Trump administration to take up to 75 “third country nationals” who cannot be returned to their home nations, the office of Palau’s president said Wednesday. In return, Palau will receive $7.5 million and other aid.

https://www.hawaiitribune-herald.com/2025/12/25/nation-world-news/palau-agrees-to-take-up-to-75-migrants-from-the-us/

Weight-loss pill approval set to accelerate food industry product overhauls

(date: 2025-12-25)

NEW YORK — Packaged food makers and fast-food restaurants may ‌be forced to overhaul more of their products next year as newly approved, appetite-suppressing GLP-1 pills become available in January, analysts say. More Americans are expected to try the drugs as a pill rather than as a shot because the medication will be cheaper and many patients are hesitant to inject themselves. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved Novo Nordisk’s Wegovy GLP-1 pill on ‍Monday, sending shares of food companies down on Tuesday. Eli Lilly’s rival medication is expected to gain approval from regulators next year.

https://www.hawaiitribune-herald.com/2025/12/25/nation-world-news/weight-loss-pill-approval-set-to-accelerate-food-industry-product-overhauls/

MKA Chairman leads move to wipe out illicit homebrew in Hanuabada

(date: 2025-12-25)

In a historic breakthrough for the Motu-Koitabu people, more than ten homebrew producers in Hanuabada have voluntarily surrendered their distillation equipment, marking a major step toward ending the village’s long-standing struggle with illicit alcohol.

The voluntary surrender followed a targeted operation spearheaded by the Chairman of the Motu-Koitabu Assembly (MKA), Russell S. Wavik, aimed at dismantling the rampant sale of "faiya-wara" and the illegal display of alcohol at the Hanuabada roadside market.

(date: 2025-12-25)

While denominations observe it in different ways, some focusing on the day rather than the historical event that occurred that shaped PNG’s religious outlook, the meaning remains the same: the birth of Christ and hope for the world. Francis Mauigoa helps Hurricanes back to the ‘Cotton Bowl’ – Rumored to be 1st round NFL Draft Pick

(date: 2025-12-24)

By

Tony Gasu

Samoa News Correspondent

Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA — Son of American Samoa – Francis Mauigoa from the village of Ili’ili, continues to wreak havoc on the football field with the University of Miami “Hurricanes” (No.10), who defeated the Texas A&M (No.7) in a historic 10 - 3 victory this past weekend. They are now scheduled to face the Ohio State ‘Buckeyes’ (No.2) in the Cotton Bowl that is set to kick off on New Year’s Eve, December 31, 2025.

Mauigoa was named Consensus All-American, by the NCAA last Friday. The 6’6, 335lbs anchors a 11-2 Miami Hurricanes team who have much improved from their 10-3 record from last season.

To be named a Consensus All-American, a student-athlete must receive First Team All-America honors from at least three of the five NCAA-recognized selectors: the Associated Press, American Football Coaches Association, Football Writers Association of America, The Sporting News and the Walter Camp Football Foundation.

According to the University of Florida’s recent media release, Mauigoa, received First Team honors from The Sporting News, the Associated Press and the Walter Camp Football Foundation. He anchored an offensive line that powered one of the ACC’s most productive rushing attacks, as Miami totaled 2,456 rushing yards while averaging 188.9 yards per game and 5.7 yards per carry. The Hurricanes also scored 30 rushing touchdowns and limited negative plays, allowing just 203 yards lost on the ground throughout the season.

Francis graduated earlier this month with his Bachelor of Science degree in Communication, earning his Bachelor’s in just three years. Most college students take four to five years to complete their degree, which makes this accomplishment even more impressive.

University of Miami graduate Francis Mauigoa, posing with his parent Fa’alialia and Telesia Mauigoa, during his graduation earlier this month, (December 11, 2025). Francis graduated with his Bachelor’s of Science in Communication, earning his Bachelor’s degree in three years – Most college students take four to five years to complete their degree, which makes this accomplishment even more impressive. [photo: courtesy]

Mauigoa who is rumored to be a first round draft pick in the 2026 NFL Draft, is the son of Telesia and Fa’alialia Mauigoa of Ili’ili. His older brother and former teammate, Francisco Mauigoa currently plays linebacker for the New York Jets Football Team.

KEIKI MISIPEKA — PERSONNEL DEPARTMENT, UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI

Adding to the significant changes within the University of Miami football program is another Son of Samoa, Keiki Misipeka. Misipeka works in recruiting and personnel and has been part of the program for nearly a year.

During his career, Misipeka has helped and assisted numerous student-athletes from American Samoa, guiding them to Division I and junior college football opportunities. He previously served as the General Manager of Football at the University of Hawaiʻi, taking over the role for the Rainbow Warriors in 2024 after spending two seasons as the running backs coach.

Prior to his time coaching in the Mountain West Conference, Misipeka served as an NFL International Scout for the International Player Pathway (IPP) Program, where he was responsible for scouting the Pacific region, including American Samoa, Samoa, Tonga, Fiji, Australia, and New Zealand.

Misipeka is the son of the late Kelemete and Iolani Misipeka of Fagatogo.

Section:

Local News

Thieves using taxis to infiltrate Gerehu 3A as community watch thwarts new crime tactics

(date: 2025-12-24)

Community leaders in Gerehu 3A are sounding the alarm on a sophisticated new tactic being used by car thieves, even as local volunteer efforts successfully drive down overall crime rates. According to community leader Penny Son, criminals have moved away from traditional methods and are now using hired taxis to infiltrate the neighborhood undetected.

These suspects reportedly use the cabs to scout for target vehicles and execute thefts, attempting to blend in with normal traffic to bypass security.

Upper Highlands welcome Christmas power outage

(date: 2025-12-24)

The residents across the Upper Highlands region are facing a Christmas without electricity following a major system failure.

Papua New Guinea Power Limited (PPL) has confirmed that the 507 Main Exporting Transmission Line, which runs from Himitovi to the Upper Highlands, has developed a "permanent fault." This has resulted in a complete supply isolation for the entire regional network.

(date: 2025-12-24)

WASHINGTON — Roughly 25,000 people have ​expressed ‌interest in joining the ‌Trump administration’s cadre of engineers known as Tech Force, a senior Trump administration official said on Tuesday, as the ‍U.S. government looks to install staff with artificial intelligence expertise in federal roles. The Trump administration will use that ​list to recruit software and ​data engineers, in addition to other tech roles, said Scott Kupor, director of the U.S. Office of ‍Personnel Management, in a post on X. ​Reuters could not independently verify the 25,000 figure. The interested candidates will compete for 1,000 spots in the first Tech Force cohort. The recruits will spend two years working on technology projects inside federal agencies, including the Departments of Homeland Security, Veterans Affairs, and Justice, among other government offices, Kupor said previously.

IRC appoints Sam Loi as Acting Commissioner General

(date: 2025-12-23)

The Internal Revenue Commission (IRC) has announced the formal appointment of Commissioner of Tax, Mr Sam Loi, as Acting Commissioner General. The appointment was made by the National Executive Council and took effect on 17 December 2025. Mr Loi will serve in this capacity until a substantive appointment is finalized.

With this appointment, all statutory powers and functions vested in the office of the Commissioner General under Papua New Guinea’s tax laws are now lawfully exercised by Mr Loi. The IRC emphasized that the transition will not affect taxpayers, tax agents, financial institutions, international partner agencies, or other stakeholders. Engagement with the Commission will continue as normal, with no changes to existing tax obligations, compliance requirements, or service arrangements.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post IRC appoints Sam Loi as Acting Commissioner General appeared first on Post Courier.

https://www.postcourier.com.pg/irc-appoints-sam-loi-as-acting-commissioner-general/

Air Niugini’s A220 first landing in Rabaul

(date: 2025-12-23)

Air Niugini successfully operated its first Airbus A220-300 commercial service into Tokua airport, Rabaul, last Friday on 19 December, marking a major milestone in the airline’s fleet modernisation and domestic network expansion.

The flight, PX 202, departed Port Moresby at 08:36 am and arrived in Rabaul at 10:07 am, carrying 101 people travelling home for Christmas.  The aircraft was accorded a traditional water salute upon arrival in recognition of the milestone occasion.

(date: 2025-12-23)

Law and order failures rooted in broken families, says Wau-Waria MP in Christmas message

(date: 2025-12-23)

Member for Wau-Waria, Marsh Narewec, says law and order problems gripping Papua New Guinea, particularly in young districts like Wau-Waria, are the result of decades of neglect in education and the breakdown of family structures, warning that the cost is now being paid in lost lives, destroyed property, and growing insecurity.

In his Christmas message to the people of Papua New Guinea and Wau-Waria District, Mr Narewec described 2025 as one of the most challenging years for the infant district, with law and order remaining its biggest obstacle to development.

Empowering women and building futures: The impact of CPL Foundation

(date: 2025-12-23)

In 2025, the CPL Foundation continued its dedicated mission to uplift women and girls across Papua New Guinea, making a profound difference in their lives through targeted healthcare, education, economic empowerment, and community support.

With over K1 million invested, the foundation focused on four key areas. In the realm of health, they screened more than 1,180 women for cervical cancer, providing onsite treatment to 84% of HPV-positive cases.

(date: 2025-12-23)

The Markham Smart Farmers Association will host its annual Battle of the Bands competition on 27 and 28 January 2026, bringing together organised youth groups from across the Markham district for a two-day community event.

The competition will be held at the Markham Smart Farmers Association Resource Centre and will coincide with the official opening of the centre on 28 January. Organizers say the event is designed to give young people a positive and structured space to express themselves through music.

Democratic-led states sue to block US consumer watchdog’s defunding under Trump

(date: 2025-12-23)

A coalition of Democratic-led states filed ‌a lawsuit on Monday seeking to prevent President Donald Trump’s administration from defunding the U.S. Consumer Financial Protection Bureau by refusing to request money from the Federal Reserve. Democratic attorneys general from 21 states and the District of Columbia filed the ‍lawsuit in federal court in Oregon, arguing that the administration’s decision not to seek additional funding for the U.S. consumer watchdog is unlawful and undermines Congress’ authority under the U.S. Constitution.

Let’s Talk Food: Buche de Noel for Christmas

(date: 2025-12-23)

Christmas is this Thursday, with family gatherings of traditional foods. One of them, a French tradition, is the buche de noel log cake, symbolizing a log that is burned during the winter solstice for good luck. Not only did the burning log provide warmth and light, but also protected them from evil spirits.

https://www.hawaiitribune-herald.com/2025/12/23/features/lets-talk-food-buche-de-noel-for-christmas/
